Date of Assessment:   2022 - 05 - 16  Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  THERAPIST   QUALIFICATIONS:  Mr. Ferland   is an Occupational Therapist with over   2 4   years of experience.   His professional  practice began in 1998 when he graduated Magna Cum Laude from the University of Ottawa and  launched himself in the world of private business. Over the years,   he   has provided services to the  automobile insurance and   legal communities as well the WSIB, Veterans Affairs and the Long -  Term Disability sector.  Mr. Ferland   has extensive experience working with individuals suffering from catastrophic  injuries. He provides assessment and treatment services as a primary Occu pational Therapist as  well as a Case Manager for individuals who sustained traumatic brain injuries, spinal cord injuries  and amputations.   He also has extensive experience working with individuals who have been  deemed to meet the catastrophic threshold on   the basis of psychological and/or psychiatric  impairments.  Over his years of working with individuals injured in motor vehicle accidents,   Mr. Ferland  developed a strong interest in the field of mental health, focussed on functional reactivation for  injur ed individuals suffering from depression, anxiety and posttraumatic stress.   His clinical  acumen has led him to be qualified as an Expert in his field by the Ontario Superior Court of  Justice.

Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   2   of   15  PURPOSE OF REFERRAL :  Mr. Bromow was referred to Ferland & Associates Inc. by his legal representative Mr. Frank  McNally in relation to   injuries he sustained in a   motor vehicle accident which occurred on   July  23, 2021.   The referral mandate was to complete an In - Home   Assessment of Mr. Bromow’s  function as it relates to his activities of daily living in addition to providing treatment to foster a  return to pre - accident levels of function.  SUMMARY OF FINDINGS:  Mr. Bromow is a 58 year - old man who was involved in a moto r vehicle accident on July 23, 2021  when his bicycle was struck by an incoming vehicle, resulting in him being thrown to the ground  resulting in being pinned under the vehicle which struck him. Bystanders assisted him by lifting  the car off of his body an d pulling him from under the vehicle.   He heard the sirens approaching  and was taken by ambulance to the Ottawa civic hospital. He was asked to stay overnight but he  chose to go home as a result of the COVID pandemic (not wanting to hold a bed unnecessaril y).  He was “stitched up”, had a CT scan and was released home. He called a taxi after signing a self -  release form and went home to rest. He was provided with a follow - up appointment to have his  stitches removed and he reported issues with his nose as he c ould not breathe out of his right  nostril.  P rior to the subject motor vehicle accident ,   Mr .   B romo w   reported   some   dental issues   and   had  history of lower back pai n.   O ver his years working in physical labour   as a tiler,   Mr .   Br omo w  reported having developed   a loss of dis c   space in his lower back at the L2 to L 4   levels.   As a result  of his lower back pain, Mr .   Bromo w was an ODSP r ecipient since 2016.   Since age 16, Mr .  Bromo w   worked as a self - employed tiler.  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr.   Bro mow   reported   lower back pain levels of 5   –  6/10 which was constant in nature. He reported that his pain “took away from my sleeping”. He  began experiencing lower back issues in 2009 to 2011 and graduall y, he began experiencing  difficulty getting up in the morning and struggles with lifting substantial loads. He worked through  the pain and would rest when he was not working.  He had approximately twenty motorcycle crashes over his lifetime without any   major trauma. He  reported minor injuries to his knees, elbows and wrists.  As a result of the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow reported that he sustained the  following injuries:  •   Concussion  •   Facial lacerations requiring stitches  •   Neck soft   tissue injuries  •   Cuts to both shoulders  •   Soft tissue injury to spine

Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   3   of   15  •   Right knee pain  Since the date of accident,   Mr. Bromow   has not received any form of physical or psychological  care. He reported that he does not have a   family physician and has largely bee n self medicating  with alcohol and cannabis since that time.   Mr. Bromow   reported that he has increased his alcohol  intake to some extent drinking 6 to 8 tallboys of beer five days per week as opposed to four days  pre - accident.   He denied making use of any   over the counter   medication . He noted “I would drink  more but I’m too t ired and don’t have the motivation to do so.”  Mr. Bromow currently presents with an array of physical symptoms, cognitive impairments and  signs of depression. He noted that he no longer socializes as he used to, is malnourished from  lack of appetite and   has as a result suffered significant atrophy, losing approximately 25 lbs of  muscle mass since the date of loss.  RECOMMENDATIONS:  Attendant Care:  Mr. Bromow is currently   independent in his management of core self - care functions. He has  decreased the frequency and quality of his self - care as a result of poor mental health and physical  pain   however he manages his activities in a modified and reduced manner without outside  assistance.   The provision of Attendant Care is not required at this   time.  Housekeeping:  Mr. Bromow would benefit from 1 hour per week of housekeeping assistance to assist with the  management of his boarding room environment   which has reportedly been left unkwpt since the  subject motor vehicle accident.   He is currently requiring this assistance as a result of ongoing  pain and poor mental health.  Assistive Devices:  The need for assistive devices will be reviewed through th e delivery of proposed Occupational  Therapy treatment sessions recommended below.  Further Occupational Therapy Interventions:  Mr. Bromow would benefit from a block of   twelve,   2 - hour OT treatment sessions to assist him in  securing appropriate   multi - disicplinary care and predominantly ,   to foster an increase in his levels  of daily activity and a resumption of pre - accident activities of daily living.   A total of six (6) OT  treatment sessions have been already provided   to establish rapport and assi st Mr. Bromow in  managing his lack of medical and para - medical support.

INFORMED   CONSENT   STATEMENT :  This therapist has reviewed issues related to   consent as per the requirements outlined by the  College of Occupational Therapists of Ontario:  •   A n occupational therapy assessment is to be conducted by this therapist, a registered  occupational therapist with the College of Occupational Therapists of Onta rio (COTO).  •   The assessment has been requested by   his legal representative from McNally Gervan law  firm.  •   The purpose of this assessment is to assess   Mr. Bromow’s   current functional status as it  relates to   his   ability to complete   his   reported pre - accident activities of daily living.  •   The proposed assessment will include: an interview, a physical assessment and also  observations of   his   ability to complete functional tasks within and around the home as well  as education on safe means of   completing activities of daily living if required.  •   Due to the physical nature of the assessment, pain and fatigue are possible temporary side  effects.  •   Recommendations   may   be   provided   at   the   conclusion   of   the   assessment.   These  recommendations may include:  o   Occupational Therapy Treatment  o   Assistive Devices  o   Referral to other practitioners  o   Support services  •   A submission for funding will be submitted to the insurer for any goods and/or services on  an OCF18   –   Assessment and Treatment Plan. The insurer may approve   or deny the plan  (in part or in whole). Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   13   of   15  Cognitive Presentation :  Mr. Bromow was a poor historian throughout this assessment process, requiring frequent access  to his phone to review dates of events and referring to a notebook he always carries with him for  notes of   what occurred on prior days. He notes that his memory   was “not great” and he makes it  a habit to write things down in his notebook so he does not forget.  ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT:  Mr. Bromow   reported that he resides on the third floor of a rooming   building   and shares   bathroom  accommodations with five   other tenants. He is responsible for maintaining his own room   and for  cleaning common areas after use. He has access to a kitchen which   he   share s   with ten other tenants  And is responsible for the upkeep of this environment after use.   He noted that his bui lding does  not have an elevator and he is required to climb and descend 3 flights of stairs to access his room.  The bathroom and kitchen are both located on his floor.   He reported that he must transport personal  care items to the bathroom each time he is t o use it and concurrently   i s   also   responsible for taking  cooking tools and ingredients to the kitchen on the plastic tray in order to prepare his daily meals.  LIVING ARRANGEMENTS/SOCIAL STATUS:  Marital Status   Married   Single   Common Law   Other  Living Arrangement   Lives alone  Children   None  ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING   (Pre and Post Accident) :  Pre and Post Accident   Self - Care Activities:  Mr. Bromow   indicated that he was independent in his performance of all self - care activities prior  to the subject motor vehicle accident. He indicated that he   would engage in daily grooming, would  prepare meals (at time more elaborate ones such as a spaghetti sauce)   and kept as active as he  could despite his physical limitations.  At the time of this assess ment, Mr. Bromow indicated that he remains physically able to manage  his core self - care functions however finds himself limited in his ability to “get motivated an d get  going”, as a result of his poor mental health.   He noted that he no longer prepares elbaorat emeals,  completing easy meals in the microwave when he is hungry “I don’ t eat much at all”.   Mr. Bromow  indicated that he has lost over 25 lbs of muscle mass   since the accident and   d iplayed his arms and  legs which show visible signs of atrophy as a result of poor nourishment and low physical activity  levels.   Mr. Bromow noted that he has become more socially isolated and has reduced his cycling  activities sign ificantly since the accident.   He noted that he will often go several days without  showering   and will wear the same clothes for several days   ina row .

Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   14   of   15  Pre and Post Accident   Home Management Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he was responsible for  maintaining his bedroom environment as well as for cleaning common areas shared with other  tenants (namely the bathroom and kitchen environments).   Mr. Dakhil ind icated that he managed  all of these activities without difficulty and that “my room was always clean and tidy” .  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromo w   noted that “my room is a disaster”. He reported that  he does not complete dishes as often as he use d to   (“they are piling up in my bedroom”).   He  declined allowing this therapist to meet with him at home due to his feelings of embarrasement  towards the state of his living environment.   He noted that he continues to maintain the shared  bathroom and kitch en environments as he did pre - accident noting that “these areas are sacred”.  Pre and Post Accident   Vocational Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he was an ODSP recipient  as a result of a disability precl uding him from completing tiling work . He continued to complete  small side jobs for 4 hours per day, completing tasks such as kitchen backsplashes   “or other easy  jobs”.  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromow   indicate that he has experienced a significant decrease  in the side work he used to complete , reporting an approximate 30% decrease in his weekly hours.  After working, he no longer has any energy or motivation to “do anything”. He would return home  to r est and would stay in his his room for most of the evening.  Pre and Post Accident   Leisure Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he enjoyed playing  outdoors with friends   engaging in the following activities:  •   Playing frisbee  •   Playing catch  •   Hitting golf balls in a field  •   Cycling (he would cycle as his primary mode of transportation in association with bus  riding).  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromow indicated that he no longer   engages in any play  activitie s and has grown quite socially isolated. He did not ride his bicycle since the accident, only  recently resuming short distance biking, which he completes with a sense of fear and apprehension.  He finds his bicycle very heavy to handle and thus he avoids   using his bicycle in tandem with use  of public transportation.

His professional  practice began in 1998 when he graduated Magna Cum Laude from the University of Ottawa and  launched himself in the world of private business. Over the years,   he   has provided services to the  automobile insurance and   legal communities as well the WSIB, Veterans Affairs and the Long -  Term Disability sector.  Mr. Ferland   has extensive experience working with individuals suffering from catastrophic  injuries. He provides assessment and treatment services as a primary Occu pational Therapist as  well as a Case Manager for individuals who sustained traumatic brain injuries, spinal cord injuries  and amputations. Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   13   of   15  Cognitive Presentation :  Mr. Bromow was a poor historian throughout this assessment process, requiring frequent access  to his phone to review dates of events and referring to a notebook he always carries with him for  notes of   what occurred on prior days. He notes that his memory   was “not great” and he makes it  a habit to write things down in his notebook so he does not forget.  ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT:  Mr. Bromow   reported that he resides on the third floor of a rooming   building   and shares   bathroom  accommodations with five   other tenants. He is responsible for maintaining his own room   and for  cleaning common areas after use. He has access to a kitchen which   he   share s   with ten other tenants  And is responsible for the upkeep of this environment after use.   He noted that his bui lding does  not have an elevator and he is required to climb and descend 3 flights of stairs to access his room.  The bathroom and kitchen are both located on his floor.   He reported that he must transport personal  care items to the bathroom each time he is t o use it and concurrently   i s   also   responsible for taking  cooking tools and ingredients to the kitchen on the plastic tray in order to prepare his daily meals.  LIVING ARRANGEMENTS/SOCIAL STATUS:  Marital Status   Married   Single   Common Law   Other  Living Arrangement   Lives alone  Children   None  ACTIVITIES OF DAILY LIVING   (Pre and Post Accident) :  Pre and Post Accident   Self - Care Activities:  Mr. Bromow   indicated that he was independent in his performance of all self - care activities prior  to the subject motor vehicle accident. He indicated that he   would engage in daily grooming, would  prepare meals (at time more elaborate ones such as a spaghetti sauce)   and kept as active as he  could despite his physical limitations.  At the time of this assess ment, Mr. Bromow indicated that he remains physically able to manage  his core self - care functions however finds himself limited in his ability to “get motivated an d get  going”, as a result of his poor mental health.   He noted that he no longer prepares elbaorat emeals,  completing easy meals in the microwave when he is hungry “I don’ t eat much at all”.   Mr. Bromow  indicated that he has lost over 25 lbs of muscle mass   since the accident and   d iplayed his arms and  legs which show visible signs of atrophy as a result of poor nourishment and low physical activity  levels.   Mr. Bromow noted that he has become more socially isolated and has reduced his cycling  activities sign ificantly since the accident.   He noted that he will often go several days without  showering   and will wear the same clothes for several days   ina row .

Date of Report:   2022 - 05 - 18  ______________________________________________________________________________  Philip   Bromow   Claim #:   Unknown   Page   14   of   15  Pre and Post Accident   Home Management Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he was responsible for  maintaining his bedroom environment as well as for cleaning common areas shared with other  tenants (namely the bathroom and kitchen environments).   Mr. Dakhil ind icated that he managed  all of these activities without difficulty and that “my room was always clean and tidy” .  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromo w   noted that “my room is a disaster”. He reported that  he does not complete dishes as often as he use d to   (“they are piling up in my bedroom”).   He  declined allowing this therapist to meet with him at home due to his feelings of embarrasement  towards the state of his living environment.   He noted that he continues to maintain the shared  bathroom and kitch en environments as he did pre - accident noting that “these areas are sacred”.  Pre and Post Accident   Vocational Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he was an ODSP recipient  as a result of a disability precl uding him from completing tiling work . He continued to complete  small side jobs for 4 hours per day, completing tasks such as kitchen backsplashes   “or other easy  jobs”.  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromow   indicate that he has experienced a significant decrease  in the side work he used to complete , reporting an approximate 30% decrease in his weekly hours.  After working, he no longer has any energy or motivation to “do anything”. He would return home  to r est and would stay in his his room for most of the evening.  Pre and Post Accident   Leisure Activities:  Prior to the subject motor vehicle accident, Mr. Bromow indicated that he enjoyed playing  outdoors with friends   engaging in the following activities:  •   Playing frisbee  •   Playing catch  •   Hitting golf balls in a field  •   Cycling (he would cycle as his primary mode of transportation in association with bus  riding).  At the time of this assessment, Mr. Bromow indicated that he no longer   engages in any play  activitie s and has grown quite socially isolated. He did not ride his bicycle since the accident, only  recently resuming short distance biking, which he completes with a sense of fear and apprehension.  He finds his bicycle very heavy to handle and thus he avoids   using his bicycle in tandem with use  of public transportation.
